ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Miscellaneous comments on study, interview, methodology relevant to this form data
Timepoint/visit label
I can only think positive when I am in a good mood.
When in a low mood, I take fewer risks.
When I feel sad, I spend more time thinking about what my moods reveal about me as a person.
When in a sad mood, I am more creative than usual.
When I feel down, I more often feel hopeless about everything.
When I feel down, I am more busy trying to keep images and thoughts at bay.
In a sad mood, I do more things that I will later regret.
When I feel sad, I go out and do more pleasurable activities.
When I feel sad, I feel as if I care less if I lived or died.
When I feel sad, I am more helpful.
When I feel sad, I am less inclined to express disagreement with someone else.
When I feel somewhat depressed, I think I can permit myself fewer mistakes.
When I feel down, I more often feel overwhelmed by things.
When in a low mood, I am more inclined to avoid difficulties or conflicts.
When I feel down, I have a better intuitive feeling for what people really mean.
When in a sad mood, I become more bothered by perfectionism.
When I feel sad, I more often think that I can make no one happy.
When I feel bad, I feel more like breaking things.
I work harder when I feel down.
When I feel sad, I feel less able to cope with everyday tasks and interests.
In a sad mood, I am bothered more by aggressive thoughts.
When I feel down, I more easily become cynical (blunt) or sarcastic.
When I feel down, I feel more like escaping everything.
When in a sad mood, I feel more like myself.
When I feel down, I more often neglect things.
When I feel sad, I do more risky things.
When I am sad, I have more problems concentrating.
When in a low mood, I am nicer than usual.
When I feel down, I lose my temper more easily.
When I feel sad, I feel more that people would be better off if I were dead.
When I feel down, I am more inclined to want to keep everything under control.
When I feel sad, I spend more time thinking about the possible causes of my moods.
When in a sad mood, I more often think about how my life could have been different.
When I feel sad, more thoughts of dying or harming myself go through my mind.
Total score (sum all 34 items)
Acceptance/Coping (sum 5 items: 4, 10, 15, 24, 28)
Perfectionism/Control (sum 6 items: 3, 8, 12, 16, 19, 31)
Risk Aversion (sum 6 items: 1, 2, 6, 11, 14, 23)
Rumination (sum 6 items: 13, 20, 25, 27, 32, 33)
Aggression (sum 6 items: 7, 18, 21, 22, 26, 29)
Hopelessness/Suicidality (sum 5 items: 5, 9, 17, 30, 34)
